body: PG3 312, approved.

Output from a blocking invocation that exceeds its time limit:
```
wsk action invoke time -b
ok: invoked /_/time with id 677ccf2ce2264c3e8701e0477c6c804e
{
    "activationId": "677ccf2ce2264c3e8701e0477c6c804e"
}
Request accepted, but processing not completed yet.
```
@cbickel @markusthoemmes FYI.

should we just have one line?

`ok: invoked /_/time but the request has not yet finished, activation id xyz`
@mdeuser, please review.

I think we need to dig into this particular activation - is it possible the action aborted abnormally?

Can we avoid dependence on whisk.system catalog then and have the controller create a ping action? (For example - I hardly ever run the post deploy playbook; now if I don't I can develop... is that right)?

wsk action invoke time -b
ok: invoked /time/_ with id 83d442d30dae4749b5517e7cf6d10e9d, but the request has yet to finish

I think there may be more than one issue here, so I'll add these for discussion

- Giving some sort of indication that a later CLI version is available.  If the CLI is changing relatively frequently, then receiving explicit notification of non-critical updates can get annoying; so I would prefer not explicitly prompting the user whenever there's an updated CLI.  Maybe a check-for-update command or some "later version is available" denotation in the `wsk property get` or the proposed `wsk --version` is sufficient for non-critical updates.
- Possibly have an CLI manifest with a high level description of what has changed since the previous version.  The user can decide if the update is worth getting.
- Provide a way to easily manually update the CLI.   I'm wary of making this automatic, but let's discuss.
- CLI/OpenWhisk compatibility check.  I expect that forthcoming OpenWhisk releases may not be backwards compatible with earlier CLI releases.  This incompatibility may vary from a total breakage to not being able to access/manage/configure a new OpenWhisk feature.  In the total breakage scenario, the CLI could block itself until the CLI is updated.

In response to @mdeuser's points:

- We can have a property in the configuration file that enables/disables automatic checking for updates, and automatic updating of the CLI. 

- If there exist some sort of change log for Whisk, we can link to that. Otherwise, we can make a CLI change log using Git. Ex: `git log --after="2017-2-2" -- tools/cli`

- Definitely need manual updating support

- We can add custom messages to the build so that they are displayed to the user when the CLI checks for an update, or display those message when the CLI runs.

I was able to successfully test this container with [docker-compose](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-devtools/pull/10) as well as Mesos and DCOS. As soon  as we close this PR the plan is to publish DCOS packages for installing Openwhisk components in DCOS in an easy fashion.

@dubeejw - re: the last bullet, I was thinking that the compatibility check is different than the CLI update check.  Both checks may occur at the same time or separately.  The compatibility check may be a mandatory check that could be performed by the CLI or OpenWhisk; although once the CLI is in it's own repo with it's own deployment cycle, this check is probably best performed by the CLI - assuming some sort of OpenWhisk/CLI compatibility table based on some sort of CLI and OpenWhisk versioning.
I submitted PR #1929 to address this issue. It uses a function scope as opposed to a module to bypass the filesystem (avoid the temporary file).

Hi @pjdurai,
a user is merely a container for API keys at this point. In the system itself it has almost no meaning.

All entitlement/visibility concerns are attached to namespaces. Each user can have access to N namespaces and in the same namespace, different users can see entities from each other.

Consequently API keys are related to namespace access, not the user. For each namespace a user has access to, she also has an API key to access this namespace.

>>> "".split("\n")
['']

pg?

Yeah, trying to deal with all string types in Python 2 and 3 is hard.  After some further reading, I think the best solution might be to decode the subprocess output to text, if necessary, and always deal with text.  

> Making the distinction easier to handle can be accomplished by encoding and decoding between binary data and text at the edge of your code. This means that when you receive text in binary data, you should immediately decode it. And if your code needs to send text as binary data then encode it as late as possible. This allows your code to work with only text internally and thus eliminates having to keep track of what type of data you are working with.

https://docs.python.org/3/howto/pyporting.html#text-versus-binary-data

So I reverted my previous changes and simply convert the subprocess stdout, stderr to text.

@jthomas this particular set of libraries seem to be too large for a zipped action (in the order of 100MB).
@mpuittinen it is probably not feasible to include all the possible client libraries in a single base image.. maybe if you base your image on a standard OpenWhisk image, pulling it from docker hub should attempt reusing the previous layers - making the cold start potentially shorter (and potentially happen only once for any action using this particular set of client libraries).
